awd_abstract_narration:
The Engineers for Exploration (E4E) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site engages undergraduate students from a broad range of disciplines in computer systems research motivated by real world challenges in exploration and scientific discovery. The site provides an intimate mentored research environment at the University of California San Diego and a structured collaboration with scientists, explorers, and engineers at our partner organizations. Past and present projects include collaborations with the San Diego Zoo Global, the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, Mexican Comision Nacional de Areas Naturales Protegidas, Belize Foundation for Research and Environmental Education, US Department of Agriculture, National Geographic Society, Hubbs SeaWorld Research Institute, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and the California Wolf Center. The participants create technology for conservation, cultural heritage, and exploration and are deployed around the world by site participants, scientists, and explorers for research expeditions in Belize, Cayman Islands, Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Mexico, and Mongolia. The site targets participants from diverse backgrounds who do not have the opportunity to participate in this type of research. The participants work in a multi-tiered mentoring program interacting with faculty, scientists, postdoctoral scholars, and graduate students. When coupled with the community building activities, this makes a positive and memorable experience, encouraging participants to pursue further research training. 

During the ten week summer program, Engineers for Exploration (E4E) site participants work closely with scientists, explorers, and engineers to develop technology that generally focuses on remote sensing with elements in robotics, computer vision, data analytics, machine learning, and visualization. For example, previous participants designed, prototyped and deployed systems to create large scale visualizations of the Maya archaeological site El Zotz in Guatemala, track endangered iguana hatchlings across different Caribbean Islands, and document ecological characteristics of mangroves in Baja California, Mexico. The primary goal of this REU site is to expose the undergraduate participants to real-world, hands-on research projects. The participants work full-time during the summer to build technology that will ultimately be deployed in the field by scientists, researchers, and explorers. The development of this technology brings together the techniques and skills from the participants' undergraduate classes with real-world problems, and thus provides a sound connection between theory and practice. The hope is that exposure to cutting-edge, applied research will motivate them to consider graduate school and become the next generation of researchers. To accomplish this overall goal, the REU site has four specific objectives: 1) Involve participants in intellectually stimulating, multidisciplinary projects, 2) Provide real-world projects with mentorship from scientists and explorers, 3) Recruit and attract a diverse population of top quality students from a variety of backgrounds in engineering, and 4) Develop mentorship, leadership, and teamwork skills amongst the post-doctoral scholars, graduate students, and REU participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Engineers for Exploration (E4E) is an experiential program where undergraduates perform computer systems research that addresses technology gaps in conservation, cultural heritage, and exploration. Real-world applications frame impactful research problems, providing participants with an inspiring, multidisciplinary research experience in topics related to embedded systems, remote sensing, digital signal processing, computer vision, machine learning, robotics, and data analytics. Projects included creating digital signal processing algorithms to automatically classify bird calls from acoustic sensors deployed in the Peruvian Amazon, developing machine learning algorithms to assess mangrove ecosystems using satellite and drone images from Baja California, Mexico, and building the FishSense underwater 3D camera system with associated computer vision algorithms to detect and classify fishes in California and Florida.

REU participants work on computer systems research problems that address the needs of our archaeology, ecology, biology, and marine science collaborators and participate in the fieldwork. The students receive an impactful research project, a multi-tiered mentor network, and structured collaboration with researchers, scientists, and explorers. REU participants developed machine learning algorithms to assess the effects of climate change on ecosystems, created drone-based radio frequency localization systems to track endangered species, and built 3D capture systems to scan, visualize, and document archaeological sites. Students were mentored by accomplished faculty, scientists, and engineers using state-of-the-art facilities to develop cutting-edge computer systems research. Weekly workshops provide professional development and graduate school preparation activities.

E4E has proven to be a great motivator to get people of all ages interested in STEM. Working on hands-on projects with tangible objectives that can help save endangered species, understand the environment, and aid in our understanding of history is tremendously appealing and rewarding to many people.

Expanding Undergraduate Research Opportunities: The E4E program focuses on multi-disciplinary research innovations targeting remote sensing technologies. These technologies have inspired students from diverse scientific and demographic backgrounds toward STEM-based research. The program has extensive efforts to provide these opportunities to under-represented groups, e.g., women in engineering, underrepresented minorities, and transfer students. The program collaborates with scientists at the San Diego Zoo Global, NOAA, USDA, the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, and archaeologists from several universities. In this program, undergraduates spearheaded research inspired by real-world challenges in conservation in close collaboration with domain scientists from those various institutions. Senior engineers and researchers guided undergraduates to perform impactful research. They work with domain researchers and learn how to communicate their findings.

K-12 Outreach: We invited the UCSD COSMOS summer school students to witness the REU Site projects each summer. The COSMOS program is a four-week summer school focused on the STEM disciplines for high schoolers. The Summer REU students presented their projects to the high school students. The COSMOS cluster “Computers in Everyday Life” got a first-hand explanation of the Engineers for Exploration projects, serving as a great source of enthusiasm and a window into the exciting applications of STEM in college.
